p: Pathogenesis of influenza in humans is actually caused by a combination of viral direct damage and host immune injury. Excessive host immune response is harmful and often results in severe immunologic injury. Infection of highly pathogenic IAV usually causes substantial immunopathology and leads to acute lung injury (ALI) and acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) with substantial morbidity and mortality. It has been reported that IAV infection can lead to the activation of toll-like receptor (TLR) signaling pathways. Lasting activation of TLR3 is proved to be harmful for IAV-induced acute pneumonia [ 9, 10]. Activation of TLR4 can determine IAV entry and tropism via MyD88 expression and p38 MAPK activation [ 11]. Inactivated H5N1 avian IAV can induce oxidative stress and ALI through the TLR4-TRIF- TRAF6-NF-κB signaling pathway [ 12]. Especially, activations of PI3K/Akt, MAPK, and NF-κB pathways are proved to be required or even support IAV replication, and are crucial in the development of ALI [ 13– 19]. In the present study, based on our previous HTS assays, we have examined the anti-IAV effect of rhein in vitro and in vivo and investigated the mechanism of action of rhein, mainly focusing on the TLR, PI3K/Akt, MAPK and NF-κB signaling pathways.
